title: California wildfires: First 'extreme red flag warning' issued as fires burn near Los Angeles
text:
Incredibly hot and dry conditions in California have prompted the National Weather Service to issue its first-ever “extreme red flag warning”, as residents and firefighters contend with damaging wildfires that have swept through the Los Angeles area.

The forecast comes as firefighters are battling a 600-acre blaze that has consumed hills near Los Angeles, and come close to the Getty Centre museum.

Meanwhile, thousands of residents have been displaced as officials warned of the devastating impacts the fire could have.

“I don’t know if I’ve ever seen us use this warning,” Marc Chenard, a forecaster with the National Weather Service, told Reuters. “It’s pretty bad.”

The weather service has issued warnings for an area covering more than 34,000 square miles. That portion of the state counts around 21 million people as residents.

The extreme fire risk has been caused in part by the Santa Ana winds, which are a regional weather phenomenon created by gusts of westward bound wind coming into the southern California coast from inland deserts.

Forecasts currently peg those gusts as exceeding 50 to 70 miles per hour on Wednesday and Thursday, which could cause sparks and embers to be whipped up into unburned areas.

Los Angeles Fire Department chief Ralph Terrazas has said that those winds may also force the grounding of water-dropping helicopters, which provide an important component of firefighting efforts.

City authorities believe the Getty fire was likely started after a broken tree branch was blown into power lines during high winds on Monday.
